verse: Now Saul was dead. After David had ·defeated [slaughtered; been victorious over] the Amalekites, he returned to Ziklag and stayed there two days.

On the third day a young man from Saul’s camp came to Ziklag. ·To show his sadness, […and] his clothes were torn and he had dirt on his head. He came and ·bowed facedown on the ground [fell to the ground and prostrated himself] before David.
David asked him, “Where did you come from?”
David asked him, “·What happened [How did things go]? Please tell me!”
David asked him, “How do you know Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?”

The young man answered, “I happened to be on Mount Gilboa. There I saw Saul leaning on his spear. The Philistine chariots and the ·men riding in them [charioteers; or horsemen; cavalry] were ·coming closer to Saul [closing in on him].
When he looked back and saw me, he called to me. I answered him, ‘Here I am!’

“Then Saul said to me, ‘Please come here and ·kill me [put me out of my misery]. I am ·badly hurt [in the throes of death; convulsions have seized me] and ·am almost dead already [yet my life still lingers].’

“So I ·went over [stood beside/over him] and killed him. He had ·been hurt so badly [fallen and] I knew he couldn’t live. Then I took the crown from his head and the ·bracelet [band] from his arm, and I have brought them here to you, my ·master [lord].”
Then David tore his clothes [a sign of mourning or distress] and all the men with him did also.

They ·were very sad [mourned] and cried and fasted until evening. They cried for Saul and his son Jonathan and for all the people of the Lord and for all the ·Israelites [house of Israel] who had ·died in the battle [had fallen by the sword].
David asked the young man who brought the report, “Where are you from?”
David asked him, “Why were you not afraid to ·kill [lift your hand and destroy] the Lord’s ·appointed king [anointed]?”
Then David called one of his [young] men and told him, “·Go! Kill the Amalekite [Come, strike him down]!” So the Israelite ·killed him [struck him down and he died].

David had said to the Amalekite, “·You are responsible for your own death [Your blood is/be on your own head]. ·You confessed [Your own mouth has testified against you] by saying, ‘I have killed the Lord’s ·appointed king [anointed].’”

verse: David ·sang [chanted; intoned; or composed] a ·funeral song [lament] ·about [over] Saul and his son Jonathan,
and he ordered that the people of Judah be taught this song. It is called “The Bow,” and it is written in the Book of Jashar [an ancient record of heroic deeds, now lost; Josh. 10:13]:
